Award.AwardTitle: Frontiers of Molecular Design and Engineering - Junior Researcher Travel Scholarships

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Molecular engineering is rapidly emerging as a new engineering discipline that seeks to address some of
humanity's grand challenges by providing solutions that rely on a bottom-up approach, where molecular concepts form the basis for proposed strategies. This grant will provide partial travel support for 25 junior US-based researchers to attend the Frontiers of Molecular Design and Engineering Symposium, that will be held on September 27-28, 2018, at the Institute for Molecular Engineering, University of Chicago. The symposium will address multiple themes within the broad interdisciplinary sphere of molecular engineering. It will provide an excellent opportunity for the junior researchers to be informed about the current state of the art of and emerging research opportunities through scientific presentations and discussions with leading scholars and experts from the US and abroad. The Symposium aims at attracting ~150 participants.

Molecular engineering carries the potential to deliver novel systems, materials and devices of unparalleled efficacy and efficiency. It is an approach that is transforming almost all traditional engineering fields and which inherently depends upon cross-fertilization of developments in physics, chemistry, biology, and computational sciences. Graduate programs aim at educating a new generation
of researchers with the appropriate skills, knowledge, and multidisciplinary framework to tackle current and future societal challenges. The proposed symposium will provide a forum to disseminate accomplishments to date, and to inform the engineering and scientific communities at large of emerging opportunities in research and education. A noteworthy feature of the symposium is that it will specifically target undergraduate and graduate students interested in molecular engineering and expose them to the latest developments. The primary aim of the symposium is to disseminate the importance and relevance of molecular engineering in the context of emerging scientific and engineering challenges facing humanity. The format of the symposium has been conceived to stimulate discussion and the exchange of ideas. One of the key outcomes of this effort will be a better understanding of the areas of molecular along with a distilled set of emerging needs and possible solution strategies. This information will be compiled into a report to the National Science Foundation and published in the journal Molecular Systems Design & Engineering to facilitate dissemination amongst the research community. Another, important outcome of the symposium will be to expose engineering students from across the country and from a variety of backgrounds and disciplines to molecular engineering, its promise and its future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Frontiers of Molecular Engineering was held at the Institute for Molecular Engineering at the University of Chicago, on the 27th and 28th September 2018. The meeting was organised in collaboration with the Royal Society of Chemistry (RSC), and was chaired by Juan de Pablo (University of Chicago) and Neil Hammond (RSC). The full organizing committee is listed below.

Organising committee:

  • Juan de Pablo (University of Chicago, USA)
  • Neil Hammond (Royal Society of Chemistry, UK)
  • Andrew deMello (ETH Zürich, Switzerland)
  • Kristi Kiick (University of Delaware, USA)
  • Niren Murthy (University of California, Berkeley, USA)
  • Paul Raithby (University of Bath, UK)
  • David Awschalom (University of Chicago, USA)
  • Claire Adjiman (Imperial College London, UK)
  • Samson Jenekhe (University of Washington, USA)
  • Yongye Liang (Southern University of Science and Technology, China)
  • Marcus Müller (University of Göttingen, Germany)
  • Yiruy Román (MIT, USA)

The meeting was attended by 127 US-based participants and 22 international participants. 

‘Molecular engineering’ is not a new term, but in its modern guise represents an emerging field that still requires greater definition. One of the aims of the meeting was to bring together researchers employing a molecular engineering approach, and try to help forge this community. We wanted the focus to be on cross-fertilisation of ideas, and to showcase similarities between approaches used in disparate subfields. Speakers were asked to target their talks at a broad audience, and to allow time for around 10 minutes of questions at the end.

The symposium also aimed to engage with more junior researchers. A poster session was therefore held, in which 45 attendees, mostly students and early-career researchers, presented their research. Prizes were awarded for the 3 best posters, and the recipients were James Crawford (Graduate Student, Colorado School of Mines), Ashley Guo (Graduate Student, University of Chicago), and Hao Yan (Postdoctoral Fellow, Stanford University).

Attendees at the symposium found it beneficial and productive. A summary of the feedback from a survey sent to the attendees is below:

  • 82% of people stated they decided to attend based on the speakers, with 77% deciding to attend because of the subject area covered. [Multiple responses allowed, 22 responders]
  • 68% of people said they decided to come because of a recommendation, and 59% because of an email they received. [Multiple responses allowed, 22 responders]
  • 90% of people rated the quality of speakers as excellent or above average [20 responders]
  • 80% of people rated the range and interest of topics as excellent or above average [20 responders]
  • 95% of people said they would recommend the event [19 responders]
  • 89% of people said they would attend a similar event again [19 responders]

Selected comments from attendees both during the meeting and as part of the feedback survey are summarised below:

“Excellent concept for a new type of conference. Good range of invited speakers and lots of networking opportunities.”

“Topic related to my field and impressive invited speakers, experts in their fields.”

“This was a wonderful symposium - I learned about how researchers from all over the world are solving diverse problems from a molecular engineering perspective in public health, energy, and sustainability.”

“Great event who brings together top researcher in molecular engineering. Very interesting topics and high quality talks.”

“The best part of the meeting was that there were plenty of opportunities to chat with colleagues and friends.”

“It was an informative and promising conference for the growing community surrounding molecular-level design.”

Matt Tirrell, Director of the Institute for Molecular Engineering, summed up the meeting as follows: “This conference demonstrates how the Institute for Molecular Engineering and the University of Chicago have become the epicenter of the emerging field of molecular engineering. This is where world-class researchers from across disciplines come to discuss advancements and promising research in the field.”
